Award.AwardTitle: Geometric Optimal Control for Locomotion of Biologically Inspired Robotic Systems

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Animals, and their analogous biologically-inspired robots out-perform traditional robots (e.g., cars, planes, boats) in many environments and for many tasks. Unfortunately, control of biologically-inspired robots differs from that of traditional robots, preventing their adoption. Achieving control of biologically-inspired robots with the same ease as traditional robots would markedly transform the field of robotics. The main challenge is that locomotion requires time-varying periodic control inputs, known as gaits, to achieve movement. The discrete nature of the gaits and their time-varying structure means that standard control strategies do not apply. It is critical that this class of robots be as simple to control as traditional robots if widespread adoption is to occur. This award supports fundamental research into a mathematical framework that will lead to simpler formulations for control of these robots. The simpler formulation will be of value to society as biologically-inspired robots are envisioned to be of great practical use for a variety of robotic application domains, such as search and rescue, defense, surveillance, and plant integrity inspection. Furthermore, biologically-inspired robots are quite popular with youth and the public. We will capitalize on this appeal to increase and broaden participation in engineering and engineering research.

Biologically-inspired robotic systems are typically nonholonomic systems that require time-varying control inputs, making optimal control-based design of trajectories challenging. Further, these systems rely on families of parametrizable, time-varying control inputs, called gaits, to generate movement. Gaits are disjoint controls, in that applying one gait precludes the use of another. Thus, not only must the control input be time-varying, but the reachability properties are gait-dependent and may require switches of control modes for some navigation goals. On account of these challenges, the development of a framework for trajectory generation and planning of these systems is still an open problem. Drawing on concepts from differential geometry, geometric mechanics, and averaging theory to exploit the geometric and temporal symmetries of these robotic systems, a reduced optimal control formulation will be derived. The connection of these concepts to multi-mode, multi-dimensional control systems will be delineated to resolve the switched, optimal control problem associated to systems with multiple gait strategies. To generate initial trajectory estimates for the optimal control solver, we will specialize a kino-dynamic path planning algorithm to incorporate the geometric and multi-gait properties of biologically-inspired robotic systems.

ProgramReference.Text: RET SUPP-Res Exp for Tchr Supp
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main research objective of the proposal was to achieve control of biologically-inspired robots with the same ease as traditional robots. Controlling biologically-inspired robots differs from traditional robots in that locomotion requires time-varying periodic control inputs, known as gaits, to achieve movement. The control equations of motion are therefore time-varying and require discrete control action over gait periods in addition to continuous control or gait tracking during a gait. This factor makes them non-standard control systems for which traditional methods do not apply. Yet, it is critical that this class of robots be as simple to control as traditional robots if widespread adoption is to occur.  Consider that quadcopters were not adopted until the underlying hardware and software included auto-stabilization and simple trajectory tracking capabilities, after which their use blew up. Thus, the main scope of the research was to provide both a theoretical framework and the associated numerical methods or algorithms for controlling biologically-inspired robots. Importantly, the framework needed to create a reduced control model for the system that looked more like traditionally engineered control systems.

We successfully applied kinematic reduction principles using averaging methods to convert the more complex motion dynamics into steady-state kinematic models. These kinematic models operated like traditionally engineered control systems.  For example, a snake robot?s movement across flat ground was reduced to a wheelchair model. We then derived a new approximate optimal control formulation for synthesizing trajectories using the kinematic models and discretely changing control parameters. These formulations needed to address the shape changes of the robot as a function of the gait control parameters. The output trajectories were used to navigate from one point in space to another, with additional error correcting feedback terms to ensure that the actual system tracked the synthesized trajectory. Importantly, the reduction is inverted whereby the inverse mapping converts the control signals back to their original form: time-periodic gait signals. In addition to a robotic snake, we applied the same ideas to a robotic salamander and a robotic cat in the lab, both walking with quasi-static gaits.  The results demonstrate that it is possible to control biologically-inspired, animal-like robots using traditional and familiar nonlinear control methods.

During the award period, we actively communicated our findings to the local Atlanta community, through tours, robot show and tell events, and use of the robots and the research to engage undergraduates in problem-based learning and research. The algorithms and software created as part of the award are available through open source repositories (github) and have been integrated into the university?s robotics curriculum in the School of Electrical and Computer Engineering. Undergraduates are exposed to optimal control methods for gait synthesis of a planar bipedal robot.

Our final demonstration or research result involved the use of a snake robot in an autonomous vision-based navigation scenario.  The snake robot is tasked with autonomously planning and navigating to a specified location while avoiding obstacles in the environment. In successfully doing so, we have demonstrated that a snake robot can indeed be used for autonomous inspection of unknown environments, thus tying together all of the research efforts that were supported by this award and confirming a hypothesized research application of the work.


Last Modified: 12/02/2018
Modified by: Patricio A Vela

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The main research objective of the proposal was to achieve control of biologically-inspired robots with the same ease as traditional robots. Controlling biologically-inspired robots differs from traditional robots in that locomotion requires time-varying periodic control inputs, known as gaits, to achieve movement. The control equations of motion are therefore time-varying and require discrete control action over gait periods in addition to continuous control or gait tracking during a gait. This factor makes them non-standard control systems for which traditional methods do not apply. Yet, it is critical that this class of robots be as simple to control as traditional robots if widespread adoption is to occur. Consider that quadcopters were not adopted until the underlying hardware and software included auto-stabilization and simple trajectory tracking capabilities, after which their use blew up. Thus, the main scope of the research was to provide both a theoretical framework and the associated numerical methods or algorithms for controlling biologically-inspired robots. Importantly, the framework needed to create a reduced control model for the system that looked more like traditionally engineered control systems. We successfully applied kinematic reduction principles using averaging methods to convert the more complex motion dynamics into steady-state kinematic models. These kinematic models operated like traditionally engineered control systems. For example, a snake robot?s movement across flat ground was reduced to a wheelchair model. We then derived a new approximate optimal control formulation for synthesizing trajectories using the kinematic models and discretely changing control parameters. These formulations needed to address the shape changes of the robot as a function of the gait control parameters. The output trajectories were used to navigate from one point in space to another, with additional error correcting feedback terms to ensure that the actual system tracked the synthesized trajectory. Importantly, the reduction is inverted whereby the inverse mapping converts the control signals back to their original form: time-periodic gait signals. In addition to a robotic snake, we applied the same ideas to a robotic salamander and a robotic cat in the lab, both walking with quasi-static gaits. The results demonstrate that it is possible to control biologically-inspired, animal-like robots using traditional and familiar nonlinear control methods. During the award period, we actively communicated our findings to the local Atlanta community, through tours, robot show and tell events, and use of the robots and the research to engage undergraduates in problem-based learning and research. The algorithms and software created as part of the award are available through open source repositories (github) and have been integrated into the university?s robotics curriculum in the School of Electrical and Computer Engineering. Undergraduates are exposed to optimal control methods for gait synthesis of a planar bipedal robot. Our final demonstration or research result involved the use of a snake robot in an autonomous vision-based navigation scenario. The snake robot is tasked with autonomously planning and navigating to a specified location while avoiding obstacles in the environment. In successfully doing so, we have demonstrated that a snake robot can indeed be used for autonomous inspection of unknown environments, thus tying together all of the research efforts that were supported by this award and confirming a hypothesized research application of the work.
